abstract: MBIA can proceed with a lawsuit claiming that Countrywide Financial committed fraud in obtaining insurance on billions of dollars of mortgage-backed securities.
snippet: MBIA can proceed with a lawsuit claiming that Countrywide Financial committed fraud in obtaining insurance on billions of dollars of mortgage-backed securities.
lead_paragraph: MBIA can proceed with a lawsuit claiming that Countrywide Financial committed fraud in obtaining insurance on billions of dollars of mortgage-backed securities, a judge ruled. MBIA’s suit contends that Countrywide “falsely represented” to the insurer, and to trusts holding the securities, that Countrywide originated the mortgage loans in strict compliance with its underwriting standards. The insurer has covered more than $459 million of losses.

headline.main: Insurer Allowed to Sue Countrywide
headline.print_headline: Insurer Allowed To Sue Countrywide

lead_paragraph: The former Newsweek publisher Greg Osberg was named publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer’s parent company after creditors won an auction to buy the business in bankruptcy. Mr. Osberg, 52, will also be chief executive of Philadelphia Newspapers, owner of The Inquirer, The Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com, pending approval of the sale in bankruptcy court.

lead_paragraph: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I’m publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially dramatic because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it marked the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and sufficient cash on hand to complete it.

abstract: Today we have a veritable puzzle-fest, as we explore the kaleidoscopic work of a fascinating modern polymath, Clifford Pickover.
snippet: Today we have a veritable puzzle-fest, as we explore the kaleidoscopic work of a fascinating modern polymath, Clifford Pickover.
lead_paragraph: Today we have a veritable puzzle-fest, as we explore the kaleidoscopic work of a fascinating modern polymath, Clifford Pickover. “Add two doses of Isaac Asimov, and one dose each of Martin Gardner and Carl Sagan, and you get Clifford Pickover, one of the most entertaining and thought provoking writers of our time,” writes Michael Shermer, editor of “Skeptic” magazine. A prolific author and futurist, Pickover has published more than 40 books, exploring topics ranging from computers and creativity to art, mathematics, parallel universes, Einstein, time travel, alien life, religion, dimethyltryptamine elves, and the nature of human genius. All of today’s puzzles were either designed by Pickover or are based on his work. For our puzzle prize we offer his latest, stunningly illustrated work, “The Math Book,” which has the intriguing subtitle “From Pythagoras to the 57th Dimension: 250 Milestones in the History of Mathematics.”

headline.main: Numberplay: The Puzzles of Pickover

abstract: On a recent Monday morning, a small-business owner arrived at work and found he had payments totaling $22,666.31 that had to go out the door. His bank balance: $355. Here’s how he gets through the week.
snippet: On a recent Monday morning, a small-business owner arrived at work and found he had payments totaling $22,666.31 that had to go out the door. His bank balance: $355. Here’s how he gets through the week.
lead_paragraph: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I’m publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially dramatic because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it marked the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and sufficient cash on hand to complete it.

headline.main: My Week in Cash Flow: Tuesday

lead_paragraph: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I’m publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially nail-biting because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it marked the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and enough cash on hand to complete it.

lead_paragraph: Yesterday, I riffed on the weekly travails as evidenced by the sale of Newsweek. Along the way, I suggested that two New York-centric magazines, New York and The New Yorker, were making a go of it where others were not. I failed to mention the chronic success of People and Us Weekly, two big celebrity magazines that may have dipped along with all other media, but continue to storm along. And people at Time magazine were particularly unimpressed by that bit of analytics, pointing out that for all their allure, neither of those New York magazines make much money. Here’s one bit from a number of lemme-get-this-straight e-mail messages and phone calls I received:

lead_paragraph: The bailout of America’s failed housing finance giants is taking on Greek proportions. abstract: It still amazes me that after a phone call and a couple of e-mails people will send me a large amount of money for an item that no one has ever seen. But they do.
snippet: It still amazes me that after a phone call and a couple of e-mails people will send me a large amount of money for an item that no one has ever seen. But they do.
lead_paragraph: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I’m publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially nail-biting because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it was the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and enough cash on hand to complete it.

headline.main: My Week in Cash Flow: Friday

lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle works a little better in the newspaper. Six shaded boxes make more sense of the theme, but since neither Across Lite nor the New York Times Java applet can do shading, electronic solvers get circles instead. It still works. There’s also a difference in the 47 Across clue because Across Lite doesn’t handle superscripts either. My geeky XPF initiative is an attempt to reduce these restrictions by extending the digital definition of crosswords in a standard way. We’ll see how far I get.

abstract: The United States will probably not face the same kind of crisis as Greece, for all sorts of reasons. But the basic problem is the same. Both countries have a bigger government than they’re paying for.

lead_paragraph: It’s easy to look at the protesters and the politicians in Greece — and at the other European countries with huge debts — and wonder why they don’t get it. They have been enjoying more generous government benefits than they can afford. No mass rally and no bailout fund will change that. Only benefit cuts or tax increases can.

headline.main: In Greek Crisis, Some See Parallels to U.S. Debt

abstract: The constant focus on fast-growth firms can obscure the contributions of female entrepreneurs. This blog intends to share their stories and start a conversation.
snippet: The constant focus on fast-growth firms can obscure the contributions of female entrepreneurs. This blog intends to share their stories and start a conversation.
lead_paragraph: When I first considered blogging about women who are business owners and entrepreneurs, I wondered whether they really needed to be singled out any more than business owners with green eyes or entrepreneurs whose names begin with the letter “M.” I was leery of addressing a vast and varied population of women as if they were all the same but somehow different — in a bad way — from their male peers. As a former editor with Fortune Small Business, I was aware that many businesses owned by women did not grow as quickly as those of some of their male counterparts — the result of complex factors that include financing challenges, the lingering effects of centuries of gender discrimination and the vastly different socialization of women and men.

headline.main: Introducing She Owns It: ‘I Didn’t Know There Were Women Out There Like Me’

snippet: In an article in this Sunday’s issue of The New York Times Magazine, Andrew Rice writes about Sam Apple, a writer and Web site director who quit his job to become a latter-day newspaper entrepreneur. Using customized open-source software, he start...
lead_paragraph: In an article in this Sunday’s issue of The New York Times Magazine, Andrew Rice writes about Sam Apple, a writer and Web site director who quit his job to become a latter-day newspaper entrepreneur. Using customized open-source software, he started an online publication he calls The Faster Times, an attempt to keep newspaper-style journalism alive in a Web-only version. Instead of paying his writers a salary or a flat freelance fee, Mr. Apple shares advertising revenue with them — a small amount at the moment, but potentially more lucrative if the enterprise takes off.

headline.main: Sunday Magazine Preview: A New-Style Newspaper Entrepreneur

abstract: Next time this owner hires a lawyer, she plans to set a budget.
snippet: Next time this owner hires a lawyer, she plans to set a budget.
lead_paragraph: My last post created a bit of a stir. As you may recall, I’m subletting new office space and was referred to a firm that specializes in real estate law by another lawyer who had done some personal work for me. My legal needs were simple: I just needed a lawyer to review a standard sublease agreement given to me by my new landlord. The post recounted how the real estate lawyers requested a $2,500 retainer and said that the total fee probably wouldn’t exceed that amount. In the end, however, the fee was $6,450 — including $60 for sending me this courtesy e-mail: “I hope everything is O.K. Take your time.”

headline.main: My Legal Lesson (Continued)

abstract: Some people are out of work not only because demand is relatively weak, but because their skill sets don’t match what employers want anymore.
snippet: Some people are out of work not only because demand is relatively weak, but because their skill sets don’t match what employers want anymore.
lead_paragraph: I had an article today about structural unemployment — the idea that some people are out of work not only because demand is relatively weak, but because their skill sets don’t match what employers want (for example, they are highly specialized auto workers, but the only local job opening is for an oncologist). The typical causes of structural unemployment are the three T’s: trade, technology and changing tastes (e.g., consumers want more iPods and fewer C.D. players).

headline.main: Jobs That Aren’t Coming Back

abstract: Avago Technologies won a patent-infringement case  and can seek an order to block imports of Emcore’s opto-electronic devices.
snippet: Avago Technologies won a patent-infringement case  and can seek an order to block imports of Emcore’s opto-electronic devices.
lead_paragraph: Avago Technologies won a patent-infringement case against the Emcore Corporation and can seek an order to block imports of Emcore’s opto-electronic devices used to connect computers in a local area network, the United States International Trade Commission said Friday. The commission it would let stand Judge Theodore Essex’s finding that Emcore’s products infringe on one Avago patent, and not a second patent, according to a notice on the agency’s Web site. The six-member commission ordered both sides to submit arguments on whether an import ban should be imposed. Avago, based in Singapore, filed the complaint a year ago, seeking to block fiber optic components like transmitters, receivers and transceivers made by Emcore in Thailand. The patent found to be infringed, issued in 1994, is related to features of optical communications systems that transit digital information using light waves. Shares of Emcore, which is based in Albuquerque, fell 11 cents, or 9 percent, to $1.15.

headline.main: Panel Upholds Infringement in Optical Device Case
headline.print_headline: Panel Upholds Infringement In Optical Device Case

abstract: Media Equation: How headlines have changed in the age of Google and other search engines.
snippet: Media Equation: How headlines have changed in the age of Google and other search engines.
lead_paragraph: In his Media Equation column on Monday, David Carr mentions Taylor Momsen, whom he doesn’t know, except that she is a mean character on “Gossip Girl” and one of the most frequently used search terms on the Web. His real subject is the way that Google and other search engines are changing the way media companies think about headlines. Once upon a time, headlines were used to attract readers by conveying simple, clear information about what was in the story. Now, on the Web, they are used to attract the attention of search engines and social networking sites, using buzz words (“Taylor Momsen!”) and double entendres. He writes:

headline.main: Media Equation: Taylor Momsen, Google Bait

abstract: With the announcement of Man Group’s acquisition of GLG Partners, the 2007 deal to take the U.S. hedge fund public via a blank-check company now looks like a bounced check for investors, Breakingviews says.

lead_paragraph: GLG Partners, the hedge fund group, got its New York stock market listing when Freedom Acquisition Holdings, a blank-check company, bought a stake in mid-2007. Then, Freedom’s stock traded above $10. Now, the Man Group, listed in Britain, is buying GLG for $4.50 a share. Sure, Freedom’s owners are getting a price they haven’t seen since last August. But longer term, it looks like a bounced check for investors, Breakingviews argues.

headline.main: GLG Partners: Rise and Fall of a Hedge Fund

lead_paragraph: Investors in technology companies should get set for a “new normal” when it comes to initial public stock offerings, according to the 451 Group, a technology investment research firm. lead_paragraph: There are not a lot of places to go for small-business advice. One of the places most frequently mentioned on this blog and in other business venues is Score, an organization that is affiliated with the Small Business Administration. If you go to the Web site, you will find that Score is a nonprofit 503c organization that was started in 1964 and has 364 offices and about 12,400 volunteers who help small businesses succeed. Its slogan is “Counselors to America’s small business.” If you go through the Web site, you will find an impressive board of directors, a variety of ways to get advice and lots of success stories.

abstract: Trying to distill the essence of your company or your message into a single word or symbol demands serious reflection and endless reduction. How does one weigh the relative value of a versatile logo versus a versatile oven?
snippet: Trying to distill the essence of your company or your message into a single word or symbol demands serious reflection and endless reduction. How does one weigh the relative value of a versatile logo versus a versatile oven?
lead_paragraph: Thinking about a restaurant name as a logo can get you into trouble. You start turning a simple “H” into an upside down fork, or you see a sailor’s compass and imagine the “S” as the first letter of Southfork. You start looking at every word on every billboard, letterhead, article of clothing or jar in your refrigerator. And then the logo of the refrigerator itself. Logos are baffling little critters; they can mislead, they can please or they can cover the globe like a virus — Samburu tribesmen in Kenya sport the Nike swoosh.

headline.main: Playing the Logo Game

abstract: The Borders Group, will raise $25 million in a private sale to an entity controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, making him the company’s largest shareholder.
snippet: The Borders Group, will raise $25 million in a private sale to an entity controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, making him the company’s largest shareholder.
lead_paragraph: The Borders Group, the book store chain, will raise $25 million in a private sale to an entity controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, pushing him past Pershing Square Capital Management as the company’s largest shareholder. Mr. LeBow, 72, will buy 11.1 million shares for $2.25 each and become chairman, replacing Richard McGuire, who resigned, Borders said Friday. The bookseller has closed stores and cut costs in an effort to become profitable after four consecutive yearly losses. Mr. LeBow is chairman of the Vector Group, a Miami-based holding company for the cigarette maker Liggett Group. Stock in Borders, which is based in Ann Arbor, Mich., rose 1 cent, to close at $2.24 a share.

headline.main: Investor Puts $25 Million Into Borders Group
headline.print_headline: Investor Puts $25 Million Into Borders Group

abstract: The Treasury Department has hired the investment bank Lazard  to advise on a potential initial public offering of the government’s stake in General Motors.
snippet: The Treasury Department has hired the investment bank Lazard  to advise on a potential initial public offering of the government’s stake in General Motors.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department has hired the investment bank Lazard to advise on a potential initial public offering of the government’s stake in General Motors, according to a federal contract posted online. The hiring of a financial adviser is the latest step in the Obama administration’s efforts to sell its 61 percent stake in G.M., which it gained when the government bailed out the automaker last year. G.M.’s chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., has suggested that the company could take the final step to repurchase the shares by Dec. 31, citing strong financial progress after years of losses. G.M. reported its first quarterly profit since 2007 on Monday. Lazard will be paid at least $7.5 million for the assignment, at a rate of $500,000 a month for the first 12 months.

headline.main: Lazard Is Hired to Advise G.M. On a Share Sale
headline.print_headline: Lazard Is Hired To Advise G.M. On a Share Sale

abstract: An article last Sunday about the risk of a double-dip recession omitted one record-setting slide in the Standard & Poor’s composite 500-stock index. In percentage terms, the decline of 4.8 percent on Sept. 11, 1986, was not the biggest one-day drop since April 21, 1933, when the index fell 4.9 percent. Other slides were larger, including the drop of 6.7 percent on May 28, 1962.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the risk of a double-dip recession omitted one record-setting slide in the Standard & Poor’s composite 500-stock index. In percentage terms, the decline of 4.8 percent on Sept. 11, 1986, was not the biggest one-day drop since April 21, 1933, when the index fell 4.9 percent. Other slides were larger, including the drop of 6.7 percent on May 28, 1962.

headline.main: Corrections: Economic View: Fear of a Double Dip Could Cause One

abstract: An article last Sunday about the challenges facing Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, misidentified the university he attended when he went to a 1975 World Series game. He was a graduate student at M.I.T. that fall, not a senior at Harvard. A spokeswoman for the chairman also says now that because it was an evening game, he might not have skipped class to attend, as he said in a 2008 speech.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the challenges facing Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, misidentified the university he attended when he went to a 1975 World Series game. But even supporters admit that the system, also known as cap and trade, is falling far short of that goal. Critics decry it as just another form of financial profiteering with little environmental benefit.

abstract: The Deal Professor examines the recent boomlet in mergers and acquisitions and finds that private equity is the leading indicator of how the takeover market is developing.
snippet: The Deal Professor examines the recent boomlet in mergers and acquisitions and finds that private equity is the leading indicator of how the takeover market is developing.
lead_paragraph: The American takeover market has become more active. It is a nervous time, however. The strength of any return is uncertain amid a market decline, the continuing ramifications of the Greek-euro crisis and a potential popping of a Chinese real estate bubble. In this environment, corporate executives may decide it is better to focus on core businesses rather than risk acquisitions. Nonetheless, in this mergers and acquisitions boomlet, we are beginning to see what the takeover market will look like if and when it experiences a sustained return anytime soon.

headline.main: Behind the Trends in an M.&A. Uptick

lead_paragraph: Ken Moelis’s boutique is bulging. In just three years, his corporate finance advisory firm has swelled to 325 people, and counting. Such growth suggests Moelis & Company has the revenue and backers it needs for now. But with all the equity Mr. Moelis, a former UBS banker, is doling out, the pressure to go public will build before long. The company started in mid-2007 with some good timing. The upheaval in the financial sector provided an opportunity to secure cheap rents, hire displaced and disillusioned bankers, and snatch clients wanting advice at a distance from Wall Street.

abstract: Taking time out of any one day to focus on hiring felt inefficient. But that shortsighted reaction was the true inefficiency.
snippet: Taking time out of any one day to focus on hiring felt inefficient. But that shortsighted reaction was the true inefficiency.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Drane was one of the many entrepreneurs who thought she could do it all. Ms. Drane is co-founder and president of Eliza Corporation, a firm based in Beverly, Mass., that uses patented technology to communicate with health plan members, often with automated calls to encourage them to take advantage of the services their plans offer. She joined Eliza in 1999, when it consisted of just two scientists and a technology that she was charged with commercializing. She recruited the chief executive, Lucas Merrow, and by 2004, Eliza had hired engineering and operations teams. But when it came to Ms. Drane’s responsibilities — sales, marketing and account management — she was largely a solo operator. That was around the time, she said, that a board member read her “the riot act,” insisting that the company would not be able to achieve scale until she started hiring.

headline.main: Finding the Nerve to Make That Hire

abstract: Josh Knapp helps us find waiting cabs and missing links.
snippet: Josh Knapp helps us find waiting cabs and missing links.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s grid by Josh Knapp looks different because it breaks one of the standard rules of crossword construction. White squares must be “checked.” That is, they must be part of two different answers, one Across and one Down. This grid appears to have ten unchecked squares. By convention, cryptic crosswords have unchecked squares all the time — here’s what the latest New York Times cryptic looks like: (Across Lite, Solution) — but they’re not allowed in the regular daily puzzles, right? What’s going on?

Bettina Edelstein speaks to John Markoff, a Times reporter who has written about how vulnerable automotive computer systems are to malicious attacks. Computer security experts from the University of California, San Diego, and the University of Washington, backed by the National Science Foundation, were able to remotely take over car brakes and other critical controls. With modern vehicles increasingly dependent on computers, the researchers say, it’s important to address these issues before they become a problem.

abstract: Comparing states’ unemployment rates with how long their jobless have to search for work.

I was curious how closely the duration of unemployment tracked with the portion of people who were unemployed, since it seems likely that people will stay unemployed longer if the are competing with a bigger pool of unemployed workers.

abstract: It only took me a second to do the math: $60 a day x 365 days x 7 years = $153,300.
snippet: It only took me a second to do the math: $60 a day x 365 days x 7 years = $153,300.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure why I’m telling this story, but here goes: When we moved into our new shop in 2002, we quadrupled our square footage. So I knew overhead expenses would be going up considerably. Some of that increase was easy to predict, like more rent. Some was not so easy, like how much our electric bill would rise. Before the move, my bill was about $2,000 a month (we have some big machines). Afterward it ended up being about $6,000 a month. That didn’t surprise me much — quadruple space, quadruple lights, quadruple heat, more guys, more machines, etc., etc.

headline.main: The Dumbest Thing I’ve Ever Done (in My Business Life)

abstract: An article last Sunday about debt rating agencies referred incorrectly to a judge’s preliminary ruling in a case involving a structured investment vehicle sold by Cheyne Capital. The judge did not say that the agencies cannot use the First Amendment as a defense.

abstract: A fond farewell to Martin Gardner with a random selection of the master’s puzzles.
snippet: A fond farewell to Martin Gardner with a random selection of the master’s puzzles.
lead_paragraph: It’s Memorial Day. As we remember the heroes who laid down their lives for freedom, let us also spare a thought for a hero of the mind, who passed away some days ago at the age of 95. When I first encountered Martin Gardner’s columns in “Scientific American” as a schoolboy many years ago, my reaction was one of awe. Here was pure intelligence incarnate, I thought, coming up with puzzles of mind-bending difficulty month after month and explaining the ideas behind them with crystal clarity. I was convinced that Martin Gardner was the smartest man in the world. The profusion of his writings, their quality and the sheer length of time that he kept on producing them, month after month, were just mind-boggling. When he retired from “Scientific American” in 1981, I was convinced that no one could fill his shoes. Although I much admired Douglas Hofstadter, who replaced him, and was a great fan of “Gödel, Escher, Bach” I just knew that no one else could keep this up for as long as Martin Gardner had. And so it proved to be. It is a tribute to Martin Gardner’s oeuvre that the final considered impression that he left  is not very different from the one seen through the eyes of a hero-worshiping adolescent.

headline.main: Numberplay: A Fond Farewell to Martin Gardner
